Definition {#definition .unnumbered}
==========

A [*locally cyclic*]{} group is a group in which every finite subset
generates a cyclic subgroup.

Properties {#properties .unnumbered}
==========

From the definition we see that every finitely generated locally cyclic
group (and, in particular, every finite locally cyclic group) is cyclic.

The following can all be shown to be equivalent for a group $G$:

-   $G$ is locally cyclic.

-   For all $a,b\in G$, the $\genby{a,b}$ is cyclic.

-   $G$ is the union of a chain of cyclic subgroups.

-   The lattice of subgroups of $G$ is .

-   $G$ embeds in ${\mathbb{Q}}$ or ${\mathbb{Q}}/{\mathbb{Z}}$.

-   $G$ is isomorphic to a subgroup of a of ${\mathbb{Q}}$.

-   $G$ is ${\mathbb{Q}}$.

From the last of these equivalent properties it is clear that every
locally cyclic group is countable and abelian, and that subgroups and
quotients of locally cyclic groups are locally cyclic.
